in performance, the obtained scores indicate an almost uniform

paragraph.expression: let avgCorrelationScores = findWithKey_ "dataset" "Average" tableData; let compareToProposed columnName = compareCols "proposed" columnName avgCorrelationScores in underOverPerformed (overallComparison [ compareToProposed c | c <- ["glo_ve", "oiwe_ipg", "sov", "spine", "word_2_sense"]])

paragraph.value: in the correlation values for the proposed algorithm,
all the alternatives except Word2Vec baseline on average. Although Word2Sense performed slightly
on some of the test sets, it should be noted that it is trained on a significantly

corpus. Categories from Roget's thesaurus are groupings of words that are similar in some sense which the original embedding algorithm may fail to capture. These test results signify that the semantic information injected into the algorithm by the additional cost term is
enough to result in a measurable improvement. It should also be noted that scores obtained by SPINE is

paragraph.expression: let avgCorrelationScores = findWithKey_ "dataset" "Average" tableData; let algorithms = ["glo_ve", "word_2_vec", "oiwe_ipg", "sov", "spine", "word_2_sense", "proposed"]; let corrScores = map (fun c -> avgCorrelationScores.[c]) algorithms; let [avg, dev] = stats corrScores in unusuallyHighLow (overallComparison ( map (fun val -> distributionOutlier val avg dev 2) (getColumn "spine" tableData)))

paragraph.value: on almost all tests indicating that it has achieved its interpretability performance at the cost of losing its semantic functions.
